dig in.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to mix something into soil by digging
dig in.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Dig some fertilizer into the soil first.
dig in.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to push a hard or pointed object into something, especially someone’s body, or to press into something
dig in.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: She dug her fingernails into his arm.
I could feel one of the hooks digging in.
He dug his spurs in and urged his horse on.
dig in.translation[0].definitions[2].def: if a group of people, especially soldiers, dig in, they make a protected place for themselves or prepare for a difficult situation
dig in.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The troops dug in along the defensive line.
We just have to dig in and hope we can turn things around.
dig in.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to start eating food that is in front of you
dig in.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: He was already digging into his pie and chips.
